content.question: Students in a lab construct a solenoid from a spring stretched along a wooden meterstick. They place one end of the spring at zero centimeters and move the other end to <math alttext="20 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math>, <math alttext="40 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>40</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math>, <math alttext="60 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>60</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>c</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math>, and <math alttext="80 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>80</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>c</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math>, as shown. How do the inductances <math alttext="L sub 20" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>20</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="L sub 40" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>40</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="L sub 60" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>60</mn></msub></math>, and <math alttext="L sub 80" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>80</mn></msub></math> of the solenoids compare at each of the four different lengths, respectively?

choices.label: <math alttext="L sub 20 equals L sub 40, equals L sub 60, which equals L sub 80" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>20</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>40</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>60</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>80</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="L sub 20 is greater than L sub 40, which is greater than L sub 60, which is greater than L sub 80" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>20</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>40</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>60</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>80</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="L sub 80 is greater than L sub 60, which is greater than L sub 40, which is greater than L sub 20" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>80</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>60</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>40</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>20</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="L sub 20 equals, open parenthesis, L sub 40 is greater than L sub 60, close parenthesis, which equals L sub 80" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>20</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>40</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>60</mn></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>80</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="L sub 20 is greater than L sub 40, which is greater than L sub 60, which is greater than L sub 80" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>20</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>40</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>60</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>L</mi><mn>80</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
